I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Republic of the Philippines for the Metro Manila Bridges Project. 
 
2.  The project will support the construction of three bridges crossing the Marikina River as 
part of the efforts of the Government of the Philippines to improve efficiency of road travel, by 
reducing the severe traffic congestion in Metro Manila. The project will also help strengthen the 
capacity of the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) in project management and 
operation and maintenance (O&M) of bridges and crossing structures, with climate change and 
disaster risk considerations. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Macroeconomic context. The gross domestic product (GDP) of the Philippines grew by 
an average of 6.6% per year during 2015–2019. The national poverty rate declined to 16.7% in 
2018 from 23.5% in 2015, lifting about 6 million Filipinos out of poverty. The Philippines had also 
enjoyed remarkable growth in employment, which grew at an average of 4.6% per year from 2015 
to 2019. This rapid expansion led to a significant reduction in informal employment. However, in 
2020,  the  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19)  pandemic  and  the  unprecedented  community 
quarantine measures used to contain the outbreak drove the economy into recession for the first 
time since the Asian financial crisis in 1998. GDP contracted by 9.5% and progress toward poverty 
reduction was reversed in 2020. The pandemic wiped out 1.7 million wage and salary jobs in the 
12 months to January 2021.1 In contrast, employment in the informal sector rose by about 
435,000. While GDP rebounded by 11.8% year-on-year in the second quarter of 2021, the 
economy is still in its early recovery phase with the unemployment rate estimated at 8.1% in 
August 2021.  
 
4.  Build, Build, Build program. Within this context, infrastructure investments are critical 
as they can provide a significant economic stimulus and have a strong multiplier effect on GDP 
growth and employment. The updated Philippine Development Plan (PDP), 2017–2022 echoed 
the need to fast track investments in transportation infrastructure with the COVID-19 pandemic 
amplifying the vulnerabilities of the current geospatial structure of cities.2 The government’s 
aspirations  behind  its  Build,  Build,  Build  (BBB)  program,  a  comprehensive  infrastructure 
development program launched in 2017 under the original PDP, 2017–2022, remain firm, and the 
implementation of the BBB program has become more imminent.3 The BBB program aims to 
increase public infrastructure spending above 5.0% of GDP annually to attract investments, 
connect regions and markets, generate jobs, and spur economic growth through infrastructure 
development. Consequently, public infrastructure spending had increased from 2.9% of GDP in 
2015 to 5.4% of GDP in 2019, dipping to 4.8% in 2020, and is estimated to reach 5.1% of GDP 
in 2021. Public infrastructure spending is budgeted at 5.8% of GDP in 2022.

5.  Metro Manila and the importance of its road-based transport infrastructure to the 
economy. Metro Manila comprises 16 cities and one municipality and covers a total land area of 
620 square kilometers. It is the country’s economic powerhouse, accounting for more than 31.8% 
of GDP.4 Rapid urbanization has been an important driver of growth in the Philippine economy. 
The population of Metro Manila is 12.9 million and is expected to reach 14.0 million by 2030.5 
Daytime population swells by an additional 3 million people now, and this figure can increase 
further  by  2030.  The city’s  transport systems  have  been  improved  and  expanded through 
investments  in  road-based  transport  (roads  and  bridges),  railways,  and  other  mass  transit 
systems in and outside Metro Manila (footnote 2). Despite these efforts, transport facilities require 
further improvement in quality, capacity, and connectivity. 
 
6.  The sustained economic growth over the last 2 decades has accelerated the pace of 
urbanization of Metro Manila, which in turn resulted in heavy traffic congestion and substantial 
time and opportunity costs for commuters and businesses. Metro Manila’s road length totals 4,889 
kilometers (km) (1,166 km of national roads and 3,723 km of local roads) and includes a well-
formulated trunk road network.6 However, the current traffic demand of 12.8 million trips per day 
is overwhelming the network’s capacity. Metro Manila had only 1 km of road per 385 motor 
vehicles in 2019, and most commuters in Metro Manila traveled at 10 km per hour on average.7 
The  government  estimates that the country  lost ₱3.5 billion  per  day  in  2017  due to traffic 
congestion in Metro Manila, and projects that such loss would rise to ₱5.4 billion per day in 2035 
if no action is taken.8  
 
7.  Key gender issues. In addition to the economic losses, the congestion affects women 
disproportionately as they comprise 50.5% of the population in Metro Manila. Most women work 
in the informal sector and need to travel both for work and for domestic and care work-related 
reasons, often during off-peak times.9 The lack of safe paths and bridges, along with the absence 
of adequate lighting in areas where these modes of transport are used, leads to gender-based 
violence, assault, and sexual harassment. In Metro Manila, three in five women have experienced 
sexual harassment in public places and during transit at least once in their lifetime.10 
 
8.  Inadequate capacity of the existing bridges in Metro Manila. One of the major factors 
contributing to the inefficiency of Metro Manila’s road network is the inadequate capacity of the 
existing 30 bridges crossing its major waterways: Pasig River, Marikina River, and Manggahan 
Floodway. These bridges accommodate about 1.3 million vehicles per day and are operated at 
or near capacity and unstable levels.11 It is critical that additional crossing structures are built over 
these waterways to decongest the existing bridges, reducing the risk of overloading them. New 
bridges are needed to also extend the life of the existing bridges and reduce their maintenance 
costs, in addition to providing safer and more accessible bridge crossings. The government,

through its Public Investment Program, 2017–2022, identified building up to 12 new Metro Manila 
bridges across the Marikina and Pasig rivers, and Manggahan Floodway.12 
 
9.  Climate change and disaster risks. Metro Manila and its surrounding areas face high 
disaster risk from natural hazards including floods, tropical cyclones, and earthquakes. Climate 
change is set to increase the exposure of people and assets to such disasters because of rapid 
urbanization in flood-prone riverine and low-lying areas. Only about 42% of waterways and 
drainage systems in Metro Manila are unclogged and desilted, which increases the time for floods 
to subside.13 Transportation systems, especially roads and bridges, bear significant impacts from 
disasters  and  climate  change,  including  traffic  disruptions,  submerged  bridges,  flooded 
pavements,  overflowing side  drains  and  cross  drainage  works,  inundation  of coastal  roads 
because of sea level rise, and road closures because of landslides.14 Other consequences include 
collapsed bridge approaches and embankments and eroded slope protection. While the transport 
sector suffers damages and losses annually, catastrophic disasters such as typhoons in 2009 
resulted in a large P7.5 billion loss in just 1 year.15 
 
10.  Capacity of authorities concerned. DPWH is responsible for the planning, design, 
construction, and maintenance of the national highways, flood control and water resources 
systems, and other public works. With the launch of the BBB program, DPWH’s responsibilities 
have increased considerably, including the O&M of large cable-stayed and suspension bridges. 
While DPWH’s mandate is ensuring the safety and service levels of transport infrastructure, in 
line with international standards and practices, its capacity will need to be strengthened to handle 
the  expanding  infrastructure  and  increased  responsibilities.16  Its technical, managerial,  and 
leadership skills also need to be passed on to a new generation of staff to ensure long-term 
sustainability of the capacity. 
 
11.  Lessons learned. ADB’s experience with financing urban transport projects provides 
several critical lessons that have been incorporated into the project, including the need to: (i) 
conduct advance planning and due diligence; (ii) ensure the executing agencies have adequate 
capacity for project preparation, procurement, safeguards, and project management; (iii) ensure 
strong integration within the overall transport network; and (iv) consider O&M requirements at an 
early stage. ADB approved the Infrastructure Preparation and Innovation Facility (IPIF) to support 
the government in preparing complex infrastructure projects under the BBB program17 and in 
addressing these issues.18 The IPIF has been instrumental in improving the project readiness of 
various ADB-financed projects, including the Epifanio de los Santos Avenue Greenways Project 
and the proposed project (footnote 12).

12.  Strategic  alignment.  The  government,  through  its  Public  Investment  Program 
accompanying  the  PDP,  has  identified  priority  programs  and  projects  to  be  implemented, 
including all BBB transport projects (footnote 12). The National Transport Policy guides transport-
related agencies on policy decisions and future investment and coordinates national and local 
efforts and support from development partners. The project is in line with the PDP and the National 
Transport Policy (footnotes 2 and 16) and is included in the plan to build 12 new Metro Manila 
bridges across the Pasig River, Marikina River, and Manggahan Floodway. The government is 
coordinating development partners in the sector, and ADB has been cooperating closely with 
these efforts.19 The project is aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy for the Philippines, 
2018–2023 in its focus on supporting infrastructure and local economic development. The project 
will support five operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030: addressing remaining poverty and 
reducing  inequalities;  making  cities  more  livable;  accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality; 
tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental 
sustainability; and strengthening governance and institutional capacity (Table 1).

B.  Project Description 
 
13.  The project is aligned with the following impact: efficiency of the transport sector enhanced 
to sustain economic growth and increase competitiveness (footnote 2). The project will have the 
following outcome: efficiency of road travel in the project influence areas improved.20 
 
19 Five out of the 12 proposed bridges are financed by the Government of the People’s Republic of China, and one 
bridge is financed by the relevant local government unit. These six bridges will be constructed in parallel with the 
three bridges to be constructed under the project. The major development partners in the Philippine transport sector 
and development coordination are described in Sector Assessment (Summary): Transport (accessible from the list 
of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
20 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The project influence areas are divided into three categories: 
(i) direct influence areas covering all bridges crossing the Marikina River from Quezon City to Marikina, major roads 
linked to the project bridges, and adjacent major roads and areas with an arrival ratio of more than 10% of generated 
trips from Marikina (Marikina and partial areas of Quezon City); (ii) indirect influence areas linked to the project 
bridges, except direct influence areas (Quezon City, Pasig, San Mateo, and Antipolo) and areas with an arrival ratio 
of 3% or more of generated trips from Marikina; and (iii) external influence areas.

5 
14.  Output 1: Three bridges crossing the Marikina River constructed. The following three 
out of the 12 new Metro Manila bridges under the government’s Public Investment Program, 
2017–2022 (para. 12) will be constructed, with a total length of 3,023.7 meters: (i) Marcos 
Highway–St. Mary Avenue Bridge (bridge no. 1); (ii) Homeowner’s Drive–A. Bonifacio Bridge 
(bridge no. 2); and (iii) Kabayani Street–Matandang Balara Bridge (bridge no. 3). These bridges 
will alleviate traffic congestion and increase vehicle speeds on the existing crossing facilities over 
the Marikina River by providing alternative routes to users, and by increasing the capacity of the 
road network in the project areas. Traffic assignment modeling conducted as part of due diligence 
in 2021 projected that future traffic volume on the adjacent existing bridges would decrease by 
16%–33% following the construction of the three bridges under the project.21 
 
15.  The bridges will incorporate climate- and disaster-resilient features, such as increased 
bridge heights to account for the projected increase in rainfall and flood levels, to enhance a flood- 
and disaster-resilient road network in Metro Manila. Taking into consideration the high number of 
pedestrians injured or killed in Metro Manila, the bridges and their approach roads will include 
sufficient  sidewalks  and  access  routes.  They  will  also  be  gender-responsive  and  meet 
international safety standards for pedestrians, including persons with disabilities, children, older 
people, and women. The project will improve the living conditions of the people in the riverine 
areas and create a more dynamic economy by providing greater access to other parts of Metro 
Manila. The project bridges will have approach roads connecting to major arterial and other roads, 
to ensure that the new bridges do not create localized congestion. While most of the transport 
using adjacent bridges crossing the Marikina River is private (cars, taxis, and motorcycles), the 
project bridges will provide additional options for travel routes for public transport and contribute 
to the broader transport system. 
 
16.  Output 2: Capacity of the Department of Public Works and Highways for bridge 
operation and maintenance strengthened. The project will provide a capacity-building program 
to DPWH staff focused on improving the O&M of bridges and crossing facilities. The program will 
include staff training and updating of the O&M manual. A separate mentoring program will be 
developed and implemented for all female technical staff across DPWH. An assessment of the 
existing  bridges  and  crossing  structures  in  Metro  Manila  will  also  be  carried  out,  and  a 
rehabilitation plan will be prepared. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
17.  Since 2017, ADB has supported the government in implementing its flagship BBB program 
by accelerating project preparation and improving the quality of the program (para. 11). ADB’s 
IPIF has supported the government in preparing large infrastructure projects such as the Epifanio 
de los Santos Avenue Greenways Project and in strengthening the capacity of implementing 
agencies (paras. 10 and 11). O&M capacity building has been identified as a critical aspect of 
past and ongoing ADB projects in the transport sector. Under the Malolos–Clark Railway Project 
and the Epifanio de los Santos Avenue Greenways Project, for example, ADB is supporting the 
Department of Transportation with capacity building on safeguards, gender mainstreaming, civil 
works contract management, and accounting.22 The capacity-building components of the project 
will assist DPWH in developing its O&M capacity for bridges and help to ensure that DPWH will 
be able to take on greater responsibilities as an implementing agency of the large planned bridges 
 
21 ADB. 2021. Consultancy Services to Undertake the Detailed Engineering Design for the Three (3) Priority Bridges 
Crossing Pasig–Marikina River and Manggahan Floodway Bridges Construction Project. Consultant’s report. Manila 
(Loan 3589-PHI). 
22 ADB. 2019. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Multitranche

6 
such as the Bataan–Cavite Interlink Bridge Project under the BBB program. The project will also 
ensure to factor potential climate and disaster risks into the planning, design, and maintenance 
of the bridge structures, to achieve flood safety levels, extend the bridges’ serviceability and life, 
and contribute to improving the government’s responsiveness to natural hazards.  
 
Box: Noteworthy Features of the Project 
 
(i)  This is the Asian Development Bank’s first project focused on constructing bridges in the Philippines. 
It will improve the efficiency of the Metro Manila road network by constructing additional crossing 
structures for a total of 3,023.7 meters over the Marikina River and decongesting existing bridges. 
(ii)  The project bridges will help to reduce traffic congestion by diverting the traffic from the existing 
bridges and road links and shortening travel distances and times for the trips to and from the project 
areas. The economic benefit from the time saving is estimated to be ₱7.9 billion ($163 million) until 
2054. 
(iii) The bridge design has adopted climate- and disaster-resilient measures. Base isolation technique 
will be adopted through the use of rubber bearing to respond to a strong earthquake. All bridges will 
be constructed with increased heights to address flood risks. 
(iv) Given the highly urbanized project areas, the bridge alignments have been developed following 
intense consultations with stakeholders, including the relevant local government units. Social 
safeguards have been designed to minimize the impact on affected communities. Gender-sensitive 
design mobility and safety features will be incorporated. 
(v)  The project will strengthen the institutional capacity for the operation and maintenance of bridges 
and crossing structures in Metro Manila under the Department of Public Works and Highways. 
 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
D.  Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 
 
18.  The project is estimated to cost $247.50 million (Table 2). Detailed cost estimates by 
expenditure category and by financier are included in the project administration manual (PAM).23 
The government will finance land acquisition compensation, incremental administrative expenses, 
associated physical and price contingencies, taxes and duties in cash, and interest during 
construction. ADB will finance civil works and consultancy services, excluding associated taxes 
and duties but including relevant contingencies.

other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. Based on the straight-line

22.  Procurement will follow ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) 
and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). The 
Bridges Management Cluster Unified Project Management Office (BMC-UPMO) of DPWH will be 
the implementing agency and will appoint a project manager responsible for the project’s day-to-
day activities. The Environmental and Social Safeguards Division of DPWH will be responsible 
for implementing the environmental and social safeguards aspects of the project. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
23.  The project will construct three new bridges, with considerations for climate and disaster 
resilience in response to rainfall and flood risks. Adaptation measures have been incorporated in 
the bridges’ alignment, elevation, and drainage systems. The bridges are also designed to meet 
the latest requirements of the DPWH design guidelines and criteria, including the new seismic 
design specifications. In consideration of the alignments, the prestressed concrete box girder type 
was adopted in the designs for bridges nos. 1 and 2. Bridge no. 3 will be a prestressed concrete 
“extradosed” bridge, which allows long-span construction with a relatively light girder and easier 
maintenance.24 It will also adopt base isolation techniques through the use of lead rubber bearing 
to accommodate a large horizontal movement of the main bridges in the event of a strong 
earthquake. These technologies are not commonly used by DPWH although they have been used 
in bridge structures for some time including other Southeast Asian countries such as Myanmar, 
Brunei, and Viet Nam. Given the acute spatial constraints in the highly urbanized areas of Metro 
Manila, the locations and alignments of the new bridges were carefully selected to ensure that 
they contribute significantly to traffic decongestion and create minimum social and resettlement 
impacts in the project areas. To enhance the view of the Marikina River, the bridges are also 
designed to be aesthetically pleasing. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
24.  Economic and financial analysis has concluded that the project is economically viable and 
financially sustainable. The project’s overall economic internal rate of return (EIRR) is 15.0%, and 
the EIRR at the bridge level ranges from 12.4% to 20.3%.25 The main benefits are vehicle 
operating cost savings, travel time savings, and a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. 
Sensitivity  analysis  was carried  out  to  assess the impact  of variations  in cost, the  benefit 
parameters, and the implementation period. The result shows that the project’s economic viability 
would remain satisfactory even under adverse scenarios. 
 
25.  DPWH  will  be  responsible  for  management  and  technical  supervision  during  the 
construction  of  the three  bridges.  After  the  construction,  DPWH  will  operate  them  and  be 
responsible for the O&M of the assets created. Output 2 of this project will strengthen DPWH’s 
capacity for planning and executing the O&M of the bridges. 
 
 
24  An extradosed bridge employs a structure that combines the main elements of both a prestressed box girder bridge 
and a cable-stayed bridge, such as girder structures and stay-towers. 
25 The EIRRs are12.4% for the Homeowner’s Drive–A. Bonifacio Bridge, 16.2% for the Kabayani Street–Matandang 
Balara Bridge, and 20.3% for the Marcos Highway–St. Mary Avenue Bridge.

9 
C.  Sustainability 
 
26.  The bridge design took into account projected rainfall levels and sea level rises to ensure 
the climate resilience of the bridges over the economic life of the project. DPWH will be primarily 
responsible for the O&M of the bridges to be constructed and will ensure that qualified staff are 
assigned to this task. The bridges will have an annual allocation from DPWH’s maintenance funds 
solely dedicated for maintenance works that would be sufficient to cover the costs of routine O&M 
activities. O&M will follow DPWH’s manual on bridge O&M, which will be improved and updated 
through output 2 of the project. The project will also assist DPWH in training its staff in bridge 
O&M to ensure the sustainability of the bridges to be built under the project. 
 
27.  DPWH finances routine and periodic maintenance of the national roads and bridges 
through government budget allocations under the General Appropriations Act every year. Analysis 
of O&M requirements for the three bridges suggests that they will account for 0.10%–0.16% of 
the  annual  O&M  requirements  for  the  total  national  road  network  under  DPWH.  General 
Appropriations Act allocations in 2016–2019 fully matched DPWH’s requirements and allowed it 
to maintain more than 85% of the national road and bridge network in good or fair condition. If 
this trend continues, the financial sustainability of the project assets will be ensured. 
 
D.  Governance 
 
28.  The pre-mitigation financial management risk is substantial, mainly because of the limited 
financial management capacity and availability of qualified staff within BMC-UPMO. Staff have 
limited understanding of financial management arrangements, the requirements for ADB-financed 
projects, and project internal control and internal audit procedures. A financial management risk 
mitigating action plan has been agreed with the government and will be implemented by DPWH 
and BMC-UPMO. Details are in the financial management assessment report.26 
 
29.  Procurement  and  anticorruption  measures.  DPWH  has  substantial  experience  in 
implementing similar ADB- and other development partner-financed projects. ADB will review 
procurement-related documents at all major milestones before proceeding with bidding and 
contract awards. Three packages will be procured to complete the project and will be financed 
under the project. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and 
discussed with the government and DPWH. The specific policy requirements and supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 23). 
 
E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
30.  Improvements in the urban environment regarding access to adequate housing and 
employment-related skills contribute to reducing poverty in the NCR. The project will help alleviate 
poverty and stimulate economic growth and employment in the NCR by facilitating more efficient 
transport, thus leading to greater mobility and better access to major employment centers in the 
region.  Improved vehicle transport  will  help  poor  and  low-income  families  in Marikina  and 
surrounding areas along the bridge alignments to access income-generating opportunities, health 
services, and educational facilities. 
 
31.  The project is categorized effective gender mainstreaming. It aims to deliver tangible 
benefits  to  women,  children,  persons  with  disabilities,  and  older  persons.  It  also  supports 
strengthening the institutional capacity of DPWH in mainstreaming gender in the planning, design, 
 
26 Financial Management Assessment Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
management,  and  O&M  of  the  bridges  and  crossing  structures.  Key  gender  issues  to  be 
addressed  by the  project include  (i)  regular  flooding,  which severely  restricts mobility  and 
commuting; (ii) safety and security issues facing women when doing tasks on foot or commuting; 
(iii) lack of safe paths and bridges, along with lack of adequate lighting, leading to occurrences of 
gender-based violence, assault, and sexual harassment; and (iv) lack of employment and upward 
career mobility opportunities for women in construction and engineering.27 
 
32.  The project proposes to address these gender issues by (i) providing a safe space for 
crossing waterways, especially for women, children, persons with disabilities, and older persons, 
while validating the safety and accessibility of these bridges with beneficiaries through surveys; 
(ii)  institutionalizing  a  mentoring  program  to  pass  on  valuable  technical,  managerial,  and 
leadership knowledge and skills from senior DPWH staff to female staff; (iii) ensuring that at least 
80% of the project staff and contractors and at least 80% of the women hired during the project’s 
construction phase—who participate in project-related gender sensitivity; HIV/AIDS; gender-
based violence and sexual exploitation, abuse, and harassment; and other related training—
report improved understanding of these issues and take them into account in their work; (iv) 
complementing these capacity-building activities by producing, in accessible formats, at least five 
information, education, and/or communication products per bridge, with consistent messages to 
promote awareness of the gender issues (para. 31); (v) ensuring that women occupy at least 15% 
of the skilled positions and at least 25% of the unskilled positions under the civil works contracts, 
generating a source of employment for women during construction; and (vi) conducting at least 
two community consultation meetings per bridge during construction, with at least 50% female 
participation at each meeting. A gender action plan has been developed, and a gender and 
development specialist will support its implementation. 
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
33.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.28 
 
34.  Environment (category B). An initial environmental examination has been prepared and 
disclosed on the ADB website on 8 June 2021.29 Most of the potential environmental impacts and 
risks  pertain  to  the  construction  of  the  three  bridges.  These  impacts  will  be  site-specific, 
reversible, and easily mitigated. They include dust, vehicular emissions, noise, vibration, waste 
generation,  and  occupational  and  community  health  and  safety  hazards.  Stakeholder 
engagement to ensure meaningful consultations was undertaken, covering representatives of 
national  and  local  authorities,  related  projects  in the same  areas,  academic  and  research 
institutions, and nongovernment organizations. An environmental management plan (EMP) was 
prepared by DPWH to avoid or mitigate anticipated environmental impacts. Detailed construction 
EMPs will be prepared by the contractors before construction. DPWH will provide oversight and 
supervision in the implementation of the EMPs. BMC-UPMO, with support from the environment 
specialist  of  the  construction  supervision  consultant,  will  ensure  EMP  compliance  by  the 
contractors.  To  enhance  DPWH’s  capacity,  the  EMP  includes  training  on  environmental 
monitoring, occupational health and safety, and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
  
 
27 International Labour Organization. 2021. Paving the Way to Gender Equality in the STEM Industry. Impact story. 
11 February. 
28 ADB. Safeguard Categories. 
29 Initial Environmental Examination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

11 
35.  The project sites are in a high flood hazard area and have experienced devastating floods 
from typhoons.30 With the projected increase in rainfall and typhoon intensity because of climate 
change,  the  proposed  bridges  are  at  high  risk  of  flooding.  Based  on  the  climate  change 
assessment,31 the annual maximum daily rainfall in the original DPWH design was increased by 
25%,32 and the projected increase in the Marikina River flood discharge, by 20%.33 The bridge 
heights will be increased by 0.5 m to ensure that the bottom soffit of the bridge structures clears 
22.6 m (bridge no. 1), 23.8 m (bridge no. 2), and 25.4 m (bridge no. 3). 
 
36.  Involuntary resettlement (category A). A draft resettlement plan has been prepared for 
each of the three bridges following ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and the Philippine 
laws and regulations. The plans have been disclosed on the ADB website on 9 June 2021.34  
 
37.  Surveys to assess involuntary resettlement impacts were undertaken by DPWH during 
project preparation, together with two rounds of consultations with affected persons in each 
project-affected area. The project requires the acquisition of an estimated 12.7 hectares of land, 
of which about three quarters are private land and one quarter is public land. An estimated 86 
households  (about  344  persons),  13  small  businesses,  and  16  employees  of  displaced 
businesses will be affected. Among the 86 affected households, an estimated 80 households will 
be physically displaced, of which 60 do not own the affected house and 20 are vulnerable 
households. Replacement cost will be used to compensate all losses. People whose livelihoods 
are severely affected will be provided with livelihood rehabilitation assistance. Among the affected 
persons, those who will be physically displaced will be provided with assistance to ensure that 
they have access to legal and affordable housing. A grievance redress mechanism will be 
established to address community concerns and complaints.  
  
38.  The draft resettlement plans will be updated based on the detailed engineering design, a 
full measurement survey, the replacement cost, and further consultations with affected persons. 
DPWH has overall responsibility for updating the resettlement plans, approving the updated 
resettlement plan and obtaining ADB clearance, securing resources, overseeing resettlement 
plan implementation and monitoring, liaising with relevant government offices, and disclosing both 
the draft and the final resettlement plans to affected persons in an understandable and accessible 
manner. DPWH will not award any works contract until the resettlement plan for the relevant 
project  area  has  been  prepared  by  DPWH  and  cleared  by  ADB,  and  will  ensure  that  no 
construction commences, or physical or economic displacement occurs, until (i) compensation at 
full replacement cost and other entitlements listed in the relevant resettlement plans have been 
paid or provided to the displaced persons, (ii) comprehensive income and livelihood restoration 
programs has been established following the resettlement plans, and (iii) DPWH has submitted a 
resettlement compliance report to ADB. 
 
39.  Indigenous peoples (category C). Due diligence during project preparation confirmed 
that the project areas do not include any ancestral domains or indigenous peoples. During the 
updating of the resettlement plans, further due diligence will be undertaken to confirm the 
categorization with respect to indigenous peoples.

IV. ASSURANCES
41. The government and DPWH have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall
conform to all applicable ADB requirements, including those concerning anticorruption measures,
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, financial management, and disbursement,
as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents.
V. RECOMMENDATION
42. I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the
Asian Development Bank and recommend that the Board approve the loan of $175,100,000 to
the Republic of the Philippines for the Metro Manila Bridges Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital
resources, in regular terms, with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 28 years, including a grace
period of 9 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with
those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board.

The project will support the construction of three bridges crossing the Marikina River as part of the efforts of the Government of the Philippines to improve efficiency of road travel, by reducing the severe traffic congestion in Metro Manila. The project will also help strengthen the capacity of the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) in project management and
operation and maintenance (O&M) of bridges and crossing structures, with climate change and disaster risk considerations.
